subject: Re: [junit] Re: Is there any way I can use a failed test invoke other function?
msgSnippet: Thank you for your help Jeff. But even I overrided the protected void runTest() throws Throwable as you said, it doesn t work. I think maybe I don t understand
messageBody:
Thank you for your help Jeff. But even I overrided the
protected void runTest() throws Throwable
as you said, it doesn't work. I think maybe I don't
understand your method well.
I tried the simplest case in my code as below, and I
found the runTest never be called while I debug it:

import junit.framework.TestCase;

public class SimpleTest extends TestCase {

public void testAlwaysFalse(){
assertTrue(false);
}

public void testAlwaysTrue(){
assertTrue(true);
}

@Override
protected void runTest() throws Throwable {
// TODO Auto-generated method stub
try{
System.out.println("Catch one");
super.runTest();
} catch (Throwable thr){
System.out.println("Catch another one");
throw thr;
}
}

}


--- Jeff Grigg <jeffgrigg@...> wrote:

> --- "Bradley, Todd" <todd.bradley@p...> wrote:
> > Not really. See this thread for more:
> > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/12878
>
> A whole set of good answers, including AOP and a
> TestRunner
> Decorator.
>
> > ________________________________
> > From: tao_dong_cn
> > Hi, guys,
> > Is there any way I can let a failed test or
> assert
> > function like assertTrue(false) to invoke my own
> > log method? thanks a head.
>
> Another thought:
> If you're only interested in logging FAILED
> assertions, then all you
> need to do is override the 'runTest' method:
>
> protected void runTest() throws Throwable
>
> Call 'super.runTest()' in a try/catch block, catch
> the exceptions;
> log and rethrow them. If you want to do this to
> *all* your tests,
> then create an abstract base class that extends
> TestCase, containing
> your version of this method, and extend all your
> test classes from
> it, instead of TestCase.
>
>
>
